_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This PSM/RMP program has been developed for the CPC International Apple Company (CPC International) System 1 facility located at 403 Market Street Tieton, Washington.  
The purpose of this program is to:
	Increase the protection of public health, the environment, and facility employees by ensuring proper emergency response and mitigation procedures when handling regulated substances.
	Assist CPC International and local government agencies in their communication and coordination efforts to improve facility safety while handling regulated substances.

This facility serves as an apple storage plant which operates one ammonia refrigeration system.  The system consists of one Engine Room and 16 Controlled Atmosphere(CA) rooms.  The type of refrigeration system used is a flooded system, using a pressure regulator to control temperature.  

The major ammonia vessels (high-pressure receiver, suction accumulator and liquid transfer unit) are located in the machine room.  Also located in the machine room are the screw compressors, which pull the vapor from the suction accumulator and discharge the vapor to evaporative condensers that are located outside, above the roof of the engine room.

The largest vessel in the machine room (high-pressure receiver) can hold 16,724 lbs of ammonia.  Following standard operating procedures this vessel will never be filled to over 80% full (13,379 lbs).  The ammonia is continually circulated throughout a closed system and never held in one vessel.

Each pressure vessel in the mechanical refrigeration process has a safety relief valve attached.  The outlet is piped to an area away from any personnel (the roof).  All vessels are fitted with three-way shutoff valves and dual SRVs.  SRVs are inspected and documented every six months, and replaced every five years.  

The chances for a leak occurring are reduced because of the following safety systems:
  Suction trap hi-level float
  High discharge pressure shut down
  Low suction pressure shut

down
  High discharge temperature shut down
  Oil pressure failure shut down
  High amperes shut down
  Computer auto timer to prevent short cycling
  Oil filters plugged shut down
  250 psi relief valves on high pressure side
  150 psi relief valves on low pressure side

At CPC Intl Apple Co all employees who are involved with ammonia, are trained to understand the safety and health hazards of this refrigerant and the refrigeration system.  Each employee is properly trained in: Understanding MSDSs; routine refrigeration system operation; emergency refrigeration system operation; emergency and normal refrigeration safety procedures:  and their role in the emergency response plan.  Management has also established a procedure to ensure that contractor and maintenance personnel are trained. 

A comprehensive maintenance and mechanical integrity program covering the equipment and system components is strictly followed.  The mechanical integrity program includes planned maintenance and quality assurance activities to be performed, inspection and testing procedures, training procedures and documentation instructions.

Standard operating procedures have been written and made available to all employees in the refrigeration department.  The development and use of SOPs are an integral part of CPC Intl's ability to maintain the quality control and quality assurance processes and ensure compliance with governmental regulations.

CPC Intl Apple Co employees are trained to follow an emergency response plan that moves all employees to an assembly area away from the facility in case of a release of ammonia.  The employees are not trained to respond to releases of hazardous chemicals.  Yakima County Fire Department has a hazmat team that will respond and take control of the situation should a release occur.  CPC Intl has provided the fire department with a copy of the Emergency Response Plan and given a tour of the facility.
